body_html:
In tensorboard, if you use the LSTMCell class of tensorflow you can visualize the kernel variable in tensorboard.
You can instead define your weights in the call method. By saying weights I mean the W_xh and W_hh.

W_xh = tf.get_variable('W_xh',
				[x_size, 4 * self.num_units], initializer=w_init)

W_hh = tf.get_variable('W_hh_i',
				[self.num_units, 4*self.num_units], initializer=h_init)

and then during training, you add

for var in tf.trainable_variables():
  tf.histogram_summary(var.name, var)
body_text:
In tensorboard, if you use the LSTMCell class of tensorflow you can visualize the kernel variable in tensorboard.
You can instead define your weights in the call method. By saying weights I mean the W_xh and W_hh.
W_xh = tf.get_variable('W_xh',
				[x_size, 4 * self.num_units], initializer=w_init)

W_hh = tf.get_variable('W_hh_i',
				[self.num_units, 4*self.num_units], initializer=h_init)


and then during training, you add
for var in tf.trainable_variables():
  tf.histogram_summary(var.name, var)
body:
In tensorboard, if you use the LSTMCell class of tensorflow you can visualize the kernel variable in tensorboard. 
You can instead define your weights in the call method. By saying weights I mean the W_xh and W_hh.

```
W_xh = tf.get_variable('W_xh',
				[x_size, 4 * self.num_units], initializer=w_init)

W_hh = tf.get_variable('W_hh_i',
				[self.num_units, 4*self.num_units], initializer=h_init)

```

and then during training, you add 

```
for var in tf.trainable_variables():
  tf.histogram_summary(var.name, var)
```
